toolCalls.name: switch_mode

args.reason: User is asking about Bob-Shell functionality (how to update the CLI), which requires searching the documentation

response.output: switched to ask mode: User is asking about Bob-Shell functionality (how to update the CLI), which requires searching the documentation

toolCalls.resultDisplay: switched to ask mode: User is asking about Bob-Shell functionality (how to update the CLI), which requires searching the documentation
toolCalls.description:
Switches to a specific mode. The mode can be one of: plan,code,advanced,ask.
plan: Use this mode when you need to plan, design, or strategize before implementation. Perfect for breaking down complex problems, creating technical specifications, designing system architecture, or brainstorming solutions before coding.
code: Use this mode when you need to write, modify, or refactor code. Ideal for implementing features, fixing bugs, creating new files, or making code improvements across any programming language or framework.
advanced: Use this mode when you need to write, modify, or refactor code. Ideal for implementing features, fixing bugs, creating new files, or making code improvements across any programming language or framework.
ask: Use this mode when you need explanations, documentation, or answers to technical questions. Best for understanding concepts, analyzing existing code, getting recommendations, or learning about technologies without making changes and without executing shell commands..
IMPORTANT: make sure you have the correct mode for the current step of the task. You *MUST* switch to 'code' mode or 'advanced' mode to start the implementation of the task or writing to *non-md*(not markdown) files.

toolCalls.name: search_docs

response.output:
## Installing and setting up Bob-Shell

Bob-Shell brings Bob's AI capabilities directly to your terminal, allowing you to interact with Bob through a command-line interface. This guide walks you through the installation process and initial setup.


## System requirements

- Node.js version 22.15 or later
- One of the following operating systems: macOS, Linux, Windows, z/OS, Linux on Z


## Installation

Install Bob-Shell using one of the following methods:


## Using the Command Palette

If you have Bob installed, you can install Bob-Shell directly from the Command Palette:

1. Open the Command Palette (press `Ctrl+Shift+P` on Windows/Linux or `Cmd+Shift+P` on macOS).
2. Type and select:
   ```
   run bobshell
   ```


## macOS and Linux

```bash
curl -s https://s3.us-south.cloud-object-storage.appdomain.cloud/bobshell/install-bobshell.sh | bash
```

if you have multiple package managers, you can pre selected package manager:
```bash
curl -s https://s3.us-south.cloud-object-storage.appdomain.cloud/bobshell/install-bobshell.sh | bash -s -- --pm pnpm
```


## Windows

```powershell
powershell -ep Bypass 'irm -Uri "https://s3.us-south.cloud-object-storage.appdomain.cloud/bobshell/install-bobshell.ps1" | iex'
```

if you have multiple package managers, you can pre selected package manager (needs at least powershell v3):
```powershell
powershell -ep Bypass 'iex "& {$(irm "https://s3.us-south.cloud-object-storage.appdomain.cloud/bobshell/install-bobshell.ps1")} -pm pnpm"'
```

Bob-Shell updates automatically. When a new update is available, restart Bob-Shell to apply the update.


## Authentication

To use Bob-Shell, you will be prompted to authenticate via w3id SSO. 
Bob-Shell will try to automatically open a browser for you to authenticate. If that fails it will display a link that you need to open.


If you still need to use Bob-Shell with api-key:
* export BOBSHELL_API_KEY=abc123
* bob --auth-method api-key


## File references

You can reference files in your prompts using the `@` symbol, just like in Bob's interactive mode:

```bash
bob -p "Explain the code in @src/main.js"
```


## Safety features

By default, Bob-Shell only uses "non-destructive" tools (e.g., "read file") in non-interactive mode. To enable writing and updating files, specify `--yolo` when you invoke Bob-Shell:

```bash
bob -p "Fix the bugs in @src/main.js" --yolo
```

> **Note:** Even with `yolo` mode enabled, Bob-Shell will **not** write or update files outside the directory where Bob-Shell was started.


## Processing output

The output contains both Bob-Shell's answer along with its "thinking" steps. To make subsequent processing of the result easier, add an instruction like _Enclose the answer in markdown tags_:

```bash
bob -p "What Java version is this application for? Use the info in @pom.xml. Enclose the answer in markdown tags" > ../bobresp.txt
```

Example result:
```
I'll check the Java version specified in the pom.xml file:I need to provide the absolute path to read the pom.xml file:
```markdown
This application is built for Java 8, as specified in the pom.xml file with the following compiler settings:
<maven.compiler.source>1.8</maven.compiler.source>
<maven.compiler.target>1.8</maven.compiler.target>
```
```


## Next steps

- [Starting and using Bob-Shell in interactive mode](start-bobshell-interactive.md)
- [Starting and using Bob-Shell in non-interactive mode](start-bobshell-non-interactive.md)
- [Using slash commands in Bob-Shell](slash-commands-bobshell.md)

toolCalls.resultDisplay: showing sections for install and setup
toolCalls.description: Search through Bob-Shell documentation files. list pages & sections.

toolCalls.name: attempt_completion

args.result:
Bob-Shell updates automatically. When a new update is available, simply restart Bob-Shell to apply the update.

No manual update command is needed - the CLI will automatically download and prepare updates in the background, and you just need to restart the `bob` command to use the latest version.

response.output:
Bob-Shell updates automatically. When a new update is available, simply restart Bob-Shell to apply the update.

No manual update command is needed - the CLI will automatically download and prepare updates in the background, and you just need to restart the `bob` command to use the latest version.

toolCalls.resultDisplay:
Bob-Shell updates automatically. When a new update is available, simply restart Bob-Shell to apply the update.

No manual update command is needed - the CLI will automatically download and prepare updates in the background, and you just need to restart the `bob` command to use the latest version.
toolCalls.description: After each tool use, the user will respond with the result of that tool use, i.e. if it succeeded or failed, along with any reasons for failure. Once you've received the results of tool uses and can confirm that the task is complete, use this tool to briefly summarize the completion of the task to the user. Do not use it until previous tool uses reported the status "Success". Optionally you may provide a CLI command to showcase the result of your work. If the user requested a specific output, display the output exactly as requested without any extra text. If the task is a question that can be answered without additional information, you *must* DIRECTLY use attempt_completion tool.
